I have only played a very tiny portion of the game, but i can tell this'll be an awesome experience.  Things similar to original game: -Evil robots wanting to kill you -Ability to look at cameras  -Helplessness in a single office chair -Lights to help you see in the darkness  Things DIFFERENT to the original game -New robots, along with the old robots (Not sure how many exactly, heard anything from 8-11 of them) - No doors -Unable to run out of power (Flashlight is able to run out of power) -Flashlight to see in dark corners of rooms. -More rooms -New sounds -Added mechanics.  So far, i LOVE the game, and i can't wait to beat the first night. Ok, MAYBE i panicked, but don't judge meh :3

Definitely not the same feeling as jumping into your office chair for the first time, not knowing what is going on and then losing all power before 5am. Despite this it is still an excellent game. Scott made the right decision by altering gameplay and removing the doors; Five Nights at Freddy's began to see many uprising strategies to easily beat the game without much to worry about, but with 11 animatronics running around, attacking from 3 directions this time, strategies have become almost useless. Five Nights at Freddy's 2 began much differently than it's predecessor. I was there, with many others, the minute it was released on steam, but the first Five Nights at Freddy's only began to see popularity after youtube playthroughs such as Markiplier's. Although I cannot get past night 4, this is a great game, I have had a lot of fun in the short time I have played and I plan to have a lot more. I rate this game 20/20/20/20/20/20/20/20/20/20! But in all seriousness,   10/10!

Now that i've had some time with this game i'm gonna write a review, if you live under a rock and don't know wat FNAF is i'll explain it. it's basiclly the horrer boom on the internet of the late 2014 period, it's a game where you take a night shift at a chuck E cheese like pizzeria. the animatronics though work at night and want nothing more than you in a robotic exoskelaton, so you know, gotta stay away from them hey, but how? Well the game used a unique system which required some stratigic skill and planning, you can't actully move and you don't have a weapon, instead you look at security cameras scattered throughout the facility. When an animatronic is outside your door you need to close it, but at the expense of your oh so precious power. This game is scary because of it's atmoshere and the inability to move or fight and because of the silence in the backround with weird noises playing with it. It's mysterious and strange story filled with mythos was also highly welcomed. This game made a massive boom of popularity across the internet [ specificcly youtube ] with let's plays and reaction videos everywhere.  about a season later in the year we're already back at freddy fazbears pizzeria, but are you getting a warm childrens tune or a fox [ or a puppet ] lunging at us instead? We have unlimited power in this sequel but I still say it's a harder game, how? Well first of all there are no doors, instead there are 2 vents next to you and a massive passage to a hallway in front of you. Also there are 6 new animatronics, 5 of which want you dead snd the other will make you vulnerble to the rest. So how do escape from their terrible grasp. You have a mask. This mask will fool most of them into thinking your one of them and will keep them at bay, but as I said there are other animatronics that you need to keep away [ conveniently the most dangerous ones ] and their own ways of being tricked seems like a hard chore. Sometimes you'll be caught in a situation where you'll never make it out alive.  This game is way harder than the original and will rquire more of your freddy fazbear skills. Overall though you should be more entertained by the mysterious story [ and substory ] and setting that ulimately fuels the game.  7.9 really good PROS:  - mysterious and cool story with a great horrer setting  - new gameplay mechanics are good....  CONS  - ....but some are a chore  - really, really hard

The first game started out scary and ended up more than a little frustrating, but I recommended it because it was a unique experience that I was glad to have had. Unfortunately for me, Five Nights at Freddy's 2, feels like the exact same game with only minor differences that do little to change the experience. The jump scares seemed more predictable, and thus were not remotely scary, and the mechanics came down to once again pressing buttons and clicking the mouse in the right places as fast as possible without making a mistake.   If you loved Five Nights at Freddy's, you will probably love this game as it really is more of the same. But for me, it is one to miss.

Watch out, it's an actual review instead of yet another joke review for this game!  The first Five Nights at Freddy's, while overhyped, is still a pretty solid game. Barely over two months later, this sequel was released. That right there should ring some alarm bells. It certainly is rushed and shows some signs of the creator jumping on to the hype train while the series is still popular, rather than taking his time with a worthy sequel.  Two of the strongest aspects of the original game's horror were how good the atmosphere was and the spooky sound design. The latter is mostly gone in the sequel, with the former pretty much missing. The first game did a good job of making the pizzeria look frightening, while still matching with the description of a place that is joyous in the day. It doesn't seem like a whole lot of time was put into recreating that feel for the sequel, as the pizzeria is simply bright and colourful this time around, with no spookiness to the appearance of the diner. The only exception is the parts and services room, but of course kids aren't supposed to be there, so no attempt to blur the line of friendly and frightening was needed.  The sound design isn't even close to matching the quality of the first game's, however some of it shows promise. With some more time testing what does and doesn't work (read: not rushing the game out in barely over two months) the sound design could have been absolutely fantastic. For example, the animatronics Balloon Boy and Mangle have their own unique sounds, which excellently use common horror techniques. Balloon Boy has creepy childish sounds and Mangle pretty much is a ghost box, constant white noise and distorted voices, showing the fear behind chaos. Unfortunately there isn't really a whole lot more special going on in the sound department. The atmospheric sounds are sadly far inferior. They do their job of indicating something dangerous is nearby and that's it. Especially lazy is the sound indicating an animatronic passing through the main hall. It took me a while to realise the sound was indicating an animatronic was so close, since, well... I'm having a hard time figuring out how 'extremely repetitive alarm-type noise' ties into someone being in front of you? Somehow the loud footsteps from the first game conveyed that expression better. Additionally, you may know an animatronic is close to you by the sounds of someone moving through the vents. Even this isn't without its flaws however, as the sound has to keep looping if multiple animatronics are active at once, and thus the sound very noticably gets cut off and resets commonly on future nights.  Oh yes, the vents... there are many more animatronics in this game than the previous one and most of them travel through the vents. This means there can be more than one in the exact same spot at one time and the only way to really be aware of this oftentimes is to simply guess. Fake difficulty, which doesn't make a whole lot of sense. This was present to a small extent in the first game, although it made more sense as those areas weren't cramped vents.  The gameplay is much less satisfying than the first game's. This installment requires manic activity from the player. While later nights in the first game certainly required the player to be on their toes, there were still brief pauses while the player had to conserve power, and observation of multiple cameras was necessary to keep an eye on the more active Freddy.  This game seems to be confused in what it's trying to do, in its attempts to be different, it actually amplifies what it may have been trying to fix. There is no longer a limit to the building's power usage, so cameras can be viewed freely. At first I assumed this meant the player could spend more time checking all the cameras instead of constantly switching back to the office to conserve power, which is a neat idea. However, it's necessary for there to be a vital reason to view the cameras. But oh dear, is that vital reason a drag in this game. There's a music box in the prize corner video feed that needs to be wound up remotely, which for some reason is only possible while looking at that camera. This means the only camera that actually ever needs to be looked at is the prize corner. This becomes MORE repetitive than looking at the office. A mechanic where at least one animatronic needs to be followed camera-to-camera would not only fill the criteria of making camera viewing a necessity, but add some variety. This was achieved with Freddy in the first game, unfortunately not the case in the sequel.  Speaking of the nonsensical remote music box winding that somehow requires looking at a video feed, there is also a flashlight in this game. You're not just restricted to using it in the office, however. The flashlight can also be used in other rooms to light up dark corners. However, you're still only viewing these rooms on a camera. How can a flashlight light up something you're only viewing on a video feed? Huh? What?  As for difficulty, this game is even harder than the first, which was not a step in the right direction. The horror also fades much more quickly this time around due to having to go through the same things over and over. There isn't a whole lot of horror in the sequel, so cue falling back on jumpscares harder than ever. Some of the jumpscares are actually pretty good, aside from being overused but then there's laughable ones like Toy Freddy and Toy Bonnie just kinda jumping around being colourful, which is supposed to be scary because a loud noise is playing at the same time.  One thing I was really looking forward to, even as my opinion on this game got more negative, was unlocking the 'custom night.' With even more animatronics to choose from than last time, I thought that'd mean even more customisation. Nope. Foxy is locked to being active even on 0. The music box winds down extremely quickly, maybe even faster than it did on night 5, and there's no setting to change this. It might seem silly bringing up an unlockable mode in a serious review but the fact is that the mode got ♥♥♥♥ed up so badly that I feel it deserves a mention. There is the nice addition of presets in the custom mode to try, which reward the player with some cute bonuses, but I'd rather have a custom night that actually feels fully customisable.  I still sort of enjoy the game, to an extent, maybe as a guilty pleasure. It's however very disappointing, and I can't say I got much substantial enjoyment out of it. The next installment in the series is apparently very close to release, so that one's getting rushed out too. I'm kind of wary about buying it. Should that one be a rushed jumpscare fest as well, it may be safe to say that Five Nights at Freddy's was a pretty good horror game that got way out of hand and spawned nothing but bad sequels that don't use any scare tactic other than jumpscares.

Alright first of all from what I played thus far, it is the most terrifying game I've ever played in my life. This WON'T LET YOU BE CALM OR COLLECTED. It is difficult that's for sure, and this game constantly gets you stressed, worried, and always fumbling about the cameras, flashlight, and music box, so many times I literally minimize the game by accident sometimes when an animatronic is at my office, like Old Bonnie and made me flip out so much. That's what clinches this game over the first, in the first, after awhile you'll get a strategy down and after awhile you'll find it less scary. In my opinion, this game doesn't have that luxury. Due to all the animatronics after you, there are so many things on your mind you'll never be calm and be constantly worried by the presence of the animatronics.   The gameplay of this game is very similar to the first, so of course it's easy for old players to jump back into, but of course the most obvious changes come that there are at least 10 animatronics after you by the end, which includes: -The New Animatronics  -The Old Animatronics -Balloon Boy -The Puppet (or Marionette) That enough is already a handful to deal with, but also you're responsible for rewinding the music box, in which everytime I do so I literally flippin out since I know someone's in the hallway or something's in the vent, and it's stressful as crap since you'll have to do it fast (but it's so god dang slow). And also, no doors. Yep, that enough got me terrified. I find myself most of the time wondering when to put it on whenever I saw something in the hallway as I worry when they'll get into the office. All of this alone, to add with the same mechanics as the first, feels like a different game, although it shouldn't. You're just too worried about everything after you, that you just think of it as a new experience.   I really only have one minor complaint, and that is with a no 'Options' tab, mainly to level audio or to maybe configure a different key for the flashlight. I found 'Control' as the flashlight button a bit annoying only because for some keyboards using Windows computers, it is right next to the Windows Start Menu button, so you may accidentally exit the game, or if you are recording this like I am, it'll end the video. It's a minor annoyance, but the game has me regretting me ever playing because it's so scary.   Now I won't say that everyone will find it as scary as me, but I think most will agree it has the horror right on. I do highly recommend it for any fan of the original, newcomers, or really just the general horror fan. Just be warned of heart attacks while playing, Fazbear Enterainment is not responsible for death or dismemberment.

Well...well..it has come and was it dissapointing?   NO!  UPDATED REVIEW ------------------------------------------   They are back once again...but with a brand new set of animantronics. These new animantronics are called, Toy Chica, Toy Bonnie, Toy Freddy, Balloon Boy, Mangle and finally the puppet! 'I never really liked the puppet...it's always....thinking....' - Phone Guy.     Is the game better/worse?    If you want more of have a challenge from FNAF 1 then you should really try this. You need to focus on more things such as the music box that you need to wind every so often to keep the Marionette/The Puppet Master away. In FNAF 1 all you really need to focus on was the doors, pirate cove and the blindspots. On the other hand in FNAF 2, you need to focus on the music box, vents, corridors, making sure you put on the mask quick enough. Sounds easy? It's not.       Do you like/hate the game?    FNAF 2 has improved in some areas. The only thing is Scott has slighty rushed this game due to the lots of people begging Scott for it to come out. The game does it justice but not that well as in FNAF 1. I would not say I hate it or I even love it. FNAF 1 has a more creepier feel. The ambience is more creepier then FNAF 2. But if Scott didn't rush FNAF 2 all the negatives would be postive. So I don't hate or love this game, guess you could say I am in the middle. (like)     What do you think of the new Animantronics/Do you think it is a Prequel or a Sequel?    The new animatronics do look nice, very kid and adult friendly. Only if they were like that in the actual game. Toy Chica's dead black eyes will always give someone the nightmares. Toy Freddy is not even that scary. Balloon Boy is just a HUGE PAIN. Mangle is spiderman but instead spiderfox. That basically sums up the new animantronics...Oh did I forget someone....the Marionette? I never talk about him...his always listening...always watching. I personally think FNAF 2 is a prequel since the Phone guy never mentions the Bite of 87. The animantronics are allowed to move around in the day but in FNAF 1 the phone guy said they aren't allowed to move around in the day. I think FNAF 2 is set before FNAF 1 and before the bite of 87.    Overall?    Overall, the game is great fun to play. The first time playing is always the most scariest since you don't know what is going to happen. It's the unknown that scares you. FNAF 2 as I said, could be improved but hey.....Scott is only working all by himself, it's amazing how he can create a game like FNAF 2 in 2-3 months.   I hope FNAF 3 will improve from FNAF 2 and is not rushed. Looking forward to FNAF 3!  Thanks for reading my review!

I actually did review FNAF 3 before this even though I got the 3rd game far after the second. Long story short, this review is far overdue, but now it's finally here because it's summer and I'm bored.  Anyways, I like how there's the most animatronics out of any game in the series, including FNAF 3 (I do not include 4 because this review was written before the fourth game came out). It's really good since you have to have variety in dating sims such as these. In this game, you have the choice of Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, Foxy, Golden Freddy, Puppet, BB, Toy Freddy, Toy Bonnie, Toy Chica, or Mangle. The only negative thing I have to say about this dating sim is that it's challenging when you want certain animatronics to give you some lovin. For example, on Night 6, I tried to hit on Golden Freddy (sorry sonic99rae), but Foxy came for my booty instead. Although it can be a negative experience not getting the animatronic you want, at least somebody in the game loves you and wants to get real dirty with you. That is the charming thing about Five Nights at Freddy's 2.  Overall, I give this game 7.8/10 because there's no Springtrap in this game (as everyone should know from my FNAF 3 review, Springtrap is my Senpai) and sometimes you just cant get that animatronic that has a crush on you off your back. Otherwise, this a good dating sim, and I'd recommend it to those who aren't picky about their animatronic boyfriend (or girlfriend).

This is one of the more scarier games, but the thing is that after hours of the same old jumpscares, it starts to get boring ,and it turns from a heart racing game, to a game that you just play through. I played it and I still could barely play it. When I got to night four, I failed ALOT. After Playing night 4 for about 40 minutes, it didn't really seem scary anymore. Foxy was always in your hallway, toy bonnie was always in your vent. Mangle was always near you, and cheeca showed up a lot too. Even though you can get used to this game's scariness, I still play it because of how deep the story goes. Even though I'm sure there are millions of theories, I dont really believe them. The reason for theat is that Scott Cawthon left sooooo many questions un-answered, so many easter eggs, it kept people playing. And that is why I loooove this game so much because of all of the secrets within. I definitly recomend playing either the first or second game. They both have so many un-answered questions, keeping the minds of people thinking.

The game could be better. The original horror aspect is lessened by the threat of power (Which in this game means Foxy is going to get you, but others can be avoided easily.) The puppet is more of a pain in the rear than anything. It does give you more of a jump the first time the music box runs out, or the first few times that old Bonnie or Chica appear when you put the camera down, but after that there is a decrease in the scare factor. I have made it all the way to night 3 so far without dying, but the game was already as challenging as night 3-4 of the original. I wish there would have been more of a haunting atmosphere, which I will admit is hard to pull off with this being a (SPOILER ALERT) prequel. I still want to know what is up with Toy Chica losing her beak when she moves around, makes her look more like a round faced Pikachu than anything, but it is still creepy when you see it. There are some glitches in the game, such as Foxy jumping out from the walls when your not looking directly down the hallway, or him popping out of your camera from time to time. These really need to be fixed, maybe by having a slightly longer cut scene for it where it forces you to look down the hallway. It wouldn't hurt as well to give the animatronics some slightly different death animation and attack screams. Just like at Chuck E. Cheese, the animatronics each have different voices so that needs to be brought out more. That's why it was hard to tell in the first game whether Bonnie was a boy or a girl at first glance. And don't even get me started on BB.  Overall, the scares are still there and are hightened by the ammount of things that are going on, the number of animatronics, and the new mechanics. The only issue is that gameplay is interupted by the music box mechanic, but it redeems itself by adding time constrainted suspence. Do you go for the music box or make sure that Foxy doesn't jump you?   Mechanics -8/10 Scares - 8/10 Gameplay - 9/10 Design - 10/10 Challenge - Very Challenging if you do not have a good strategy Rage - Minor Raging early on, but get over it. Glitch Fixes - Foxy coming from walls and cameras, Toy Chica's beak dissapearing(?)  Overall - 8.5/10  I Highly Recommend this game and I hope you all enjoy it. In comparison to other games in its genre, Five Nights at Freddy's generally presents itself well and uses its minimalistic presentation to haunt the player further. Beyond simply a jumpscare festival, as some would dismiss it as, all of the small details come together to create a true experience of anxiety and tension with each play. Interestingly, it is a game that shifts from a straight horror experience into a challenge, presenting the player with more play time through the challenging gameplay that, although somewhat random, feels very rewarding when you execute properly.  In comparison with the firse Five Nights game, this game has much more polish and mechanical diversity than the old one, including the unique challenge presets in custom night, beyond simply cranking up everyone's difficulty all the way. This game keeps the tense atmosphere of the first and adds so much more. I fully recommend this to any horror fan, even if you didn't really like the first game. The pacing is quicker and more frenetic in this one, so this should be right up your alley.

Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

10/10  Every aspect of this game is truly amazing. The amount of thought put into this game is insane, and there's a little of everything in this game. You have the intense atmosphere for the thrill seekers. Non-stop jump scares for the Horror gamers. You have 10/20 mode for the over achievers. You have an amazing, solid, back story to it, that leaves just enough for you to start making your own crazy theroies, for the Lore crazy and the try hard theorist.  You have endless hours of gameplay for the determined. You have the ESC key for the first time horror gamer. You have a unique, original genre of gaming, for the guy who will play any game other then Call of Duty. You have 9 cute little plushy collectables via night 7, for the 'gotta get 100%' gamer. So to summerize, just because the concept of being stalked and horrifically murdered by 10 animatronics and a possessed marionette doesn't scare you, there's still something in this game for you.

This is the best and worst game I have ever played in my life. Period. I played the original Five Nights at Freddy's. It was great, but it got really repetitive after a while. This game.. it's just too much. First of all, in FNAF 1, you only have five animatronics attacking you. In this game, you have 11. This gets reaaaally hard in your final nights, when you have to defend against all of them at once. This game improves on the controls on the first game; it's a lot harder to make mistakes. However, this comes at the price of having to use every tool at your disposal i.e. the flashlight, the camera, the Freddy mask. And the reason this game doesn't have a lot of rage-quit dislikes is because pretty much every time you die, it's your fault.  10/10  PROS +Over 10+ hours of gameplay +Doesn't get boring super fast +Great graphics and art style +Lots of plot details and secrets, if you're into that stuff +Bonus unlockables on the custom night +Really satisfying when you actually win  CONS -Gets super hard after the first few nights -Game strives on perfection or death -Can get SUUUUPER tense -Jumpscares. Lots and lots of jumpscares -Messes with your head

My personal rating: A fantastic, freaky prequel!  10/10 !  Persuasion to buy this game: If you thought that Five Nights at Freddy's wasn't a challenge, this is a new flavor for you! Defend yourself against Bonnie, Freddy, Chica, Foxy, Bonnie #2, Freddy #2, Chica #2, Foxy #2 (Mangle), Balloon Boy, and Golden Freddy. Golden Freddy is now a part of this game (if you did not already know), and is now a character to avoid. Your goal is to take the Night Shift which is from 12:00 to 6:00 AM without parishing a horrible death, and avoid the 'music box' from stopping. You'll know what happens soon if you don't know what the Marionette is. The same engine used to make the first game aswell as this one, and the graphics compared to the last game is unbelievable! It's very difficult to survive at time, so be extremely cautious. Discover more clues about the Five Nights at Freddy's theory, thanks to the animatronics. Now that I think about it, this wasn't really a persuasion, but if you liked the first game, you'll like this a whole lot more! HOVER YOUR MOUSE OVER THE BLACK BARS FOR SPOILERS!    A little bit about the enemies Bonnie, Chica, and Freddy all have the same actions and behaviors. I'm talking about the 1.0 animatronics of course. What I mean by the same actions and behaviors is that at any random moment sometimes on some certain nights, one of the old animatronics appear in your office with a spooky position. Freddy has his arm reaching towards you, Chica is kind of in the position where you're playing Prop Hunt on Garry's Mod, and when you're the old man stoff-posed prop, and Bonnie has nearly the same action. Foxy stands very distant in the hallway and will kill you at any random moment if you don't check in on him. *Cough*'FLASHLIGHT!'*Cough* Anyways, this 'Mangle' character was supposed to be known as Foxy 2.0. Upon building this animatronic, the employees didn't have enough parts, so they scrapped Mangle and left it as a toy that you could mantle and dismantle. I'm not sure if anyone knows why Mangle is known as Mangle. But let's continue. Freddy 2.0, and Chica 2.0 can appear in the hallway aswell. Just keep checking in on them and you'll be safe(r). However, Bonnie 2.0 can only appear in the bottom-right vent if he's coming to you. If you're in your office, and you hear things rattling around like someone's in the vents, check there. If you see an animatronic's face in the vents, put your mask on until you hear more vent noises, in which case, the entities will flee. Now let's get to the Marionette. No one knows how this puppet came to be, but he was the first one that came to be a member of the restaurant. If you have seen the minigame, you play as the marionette and you revive the kids which are known as the 4 animatronics that you know and love today. Did he revive Golden Freddy? No one knows. Anyways, the Marionette is one of the most important entities you'll ever encounter in Five Nights at Freddy's 2. Why, you may ask? Because you have to wind up the box every single few seconds or so to keep him from questioning why the music stopped. Why does the Marionette come to your office after you 'forget' to wind up the box, you may ask. It's because if there's no music in the room he's in, so in which case, he searches for some, in which case, your office. I don't understand why, but okay. 2 more lovely animatronics to go! Let's get onto Balloon Boy. This is for people on night 2, 3, and up. Balloon Boy is the one of the most hated enemies. I have not encountered him ever, but I'd know how it'll feel if I did. He permanently disables your flashlight, which will cause Freddy 1.0 to jump out of the hallway and kill you. And now the most lovely animatronic who you though started it all. Golden Freddy. He is a menacing, devilish little fiend, and I assure you he will give you a heart attack. There's no real reason why he appears in your office, but encountering him will make you sh*t enough bricks to build the Wall of China. If you see his face in the hallway when you enable your flashlight, I'm pretty sure he appears in your office afterwards. No one knows why he's there, but you have to be as fast as equipping your mask as you are when the old animatronics are in your office.  Now the 2 easter egg entities you will hardly ever see This entity is known as ' Shadow Bonnie '. As my friend told me, you have a 1 out of a 5000% chance to encounter him, and it's pretty believable considering he is pretty rare and unexpected to find. He has no reason to be in your office at the time, but you will notice him. People say that he may even be a creepy enemy that will appear in Five Nights at Freddy's 3. The theory of the game hasn't been solved yet, so it may be possible that Scott will wrap it up in another sequel.  Now for the final enemy which is pretty difficult to see, and has no reason of being there. This wierdo is known as ' Balloon Girl '. When you see the table of plushies that are the animatronics in your office, how about looking under the table. Pretty creepy, huh? Balloon Boy and Balloon Girl are like a spitting image, as which they look very alike. The only difference I saw was the eye color.  Time to wrap this up with a sappy ending. This put a lot of time and thought into making, and if you read it all, thank you. If you never knew about some of this stuff, feel free to comment on this review. It would support me a lot.

I'm going to give an honest review, that many of you deciding whether or not to buy the game can trust. I would give this game 3.5 stars. It's more or less the same game as FNAF 1, with a few extra features/robots. 3 or so of the robots, I wouldn't even consider enemies/characters, as they only jump up occasionally to test your reaction time. Night 3 & 4 were good, a nice level of challenge without it being too hard. Night 5, very hard, but doable after a bunch of tries. Night 6, get ready to rage. I tried it at least 20, times, and eventually had to resort to cheat engine and slowing the game down to .5, and even then, there was still too much going on. A challenging game is good, but not to the point like this where it becomes an annoying waste of time that makes you want to punch your monitor.  The custom night is a fail. 2 screens are blocked out the whole night, you cannot disable or slow down the marionette (the most annoying part of this game), and even if you seemingly disable a robot entirely, it still remains very active (as active as it would be on, say night 3).  I think it was rushed. It could have been leveled better and more balanced, and could have had a few more features. There really isn't any reason at all to look at the other cameras (besides prize center) other than for fun and exploring. I wish he had added an element where you actually NEEDED to check the cameras to survive/strategize.

(Before I start, don't get me wrong... I like this game.) In FNaF1 the main object of the game is watching the cameras, but now the cameras are only used to wind up the Marionette, then right when you put your camera down you slide on the Freddy mask. The Marionette ruins the object of watching the cameras to protect yourself from the animatronics. Now that there is 9 moving animatronics (not including Golden Freddy and the Marionette.) you have to watch the vents and the hallway while playing with the Marionette. When watching the cameras you have to flip to the Marionette then slide down to find Chica or Bonnie staring at you after sliding on the Freddy mask and learning its too late. Without the Marionette this game would be a lot better, having to watch the Marionette, check the vents and look in the hallway ruins your chance of being able to watch the cameras without dying.  With all the animatronics constantly popping up its stupid because you could not see them in the hallway or vents then you flip up the cameras then they're there, and with Chica and Bonnie if you take and extra second longer than the other animatronics you're dead.   The Multitasking is Real. When trying to deal with 11 glitchy animatronics, you have to constantly check vents and the hallway( like I already said) while playing with the music box you will become a MLG multitasker. The point of the Freddy mask if to save you from the OP animatronics, Scott is training us for FNaF3, where there is 30 animatronics you have 30 different masks to wear. I'm kidding, but all in all you have to learn to multitask on this dissapointing prequel. Yes its a prequel, tell me what you think of this review and i'll try to respond as fast as I can.

I've heard some people say that FNAF 2 isn't as scary as the first game, I've heard some people say it's scarier than the first game, and I've heard quite a few trolls in between as well... Me? I don't care whether it's more or less scary than the first! After all, we have so much more to look out for in the second installment that we can't afford to get scared. The first game was in essence just 'watch your sides and don't forget about Foxy,' which is pretty scary in itself. But here we have a game where you can't just wall yourself into your office: Your only defence is a mask and a flashlight. Yes, the building can't run out of power, but if your flashlight dies then Foxy will quite literally eat you up. Some have complained that all the new animatronics makes this game too 'crowded' to be scary. That's nonsense! If just one animatronic got to you in the first game you were dead, and it was hard enough to keep four of them out of your office with security doors! Now we have 11 of them, and no doors! Where the first game made you use up a bit too much power, this game simply needs to distract you for one second to let one robot inside. Sure, you can fool most of them with the mask, but can you put it on the same second you spot the animatronics in your office? If not, then I advise you to get Quick or Be Dead. Think you've got what it takes? Well, you won't know you're wrong until it's too late... And then there's the constant task of winding the music box... FNAF 2 isn't just a horrifying game and it's not just a hard game: FNAF 2 is a game that'll test both your restraint and your quickness, and treat you to some lovely images of yourself screaming if you fail. I personally can't wait until the third game comes out! And yes, there will be a third, just as certain as your screams are when you lose yourself to this excellent sequel! Now excuse me, I have to wind up the music box...

If you've played the first game, chances are you're tempted to buy this, if you are going to buy this, you might want to consider looking at the pros and cons;  Pros: -Fun new gameplay mechanics to play around with. -Challenge increased quite a bit (I'm not even joking, it is REALLY hard, get ready to die again and again and AGAIN). -All the animatronics from the first game are back (including Golden Freddy) and look a lot scarier, especially Chica. -All the animatronics in this game sound way more intimidating than the first game, rather than high pitched screams, they roar with voices quite a bit deeper this time around. -A lot more backstory, you're probably aware of the bite of '87, the five missing children, etc. In this game you get a better look at what's going on, it answers some questions, and leaves some unanswered.  Cons: -Jumpscares aren't quite as scary as the first game, sure the animatronics sound like more of a threat in this one, but you get a little too much time to prepare yourself for the most part, unless Foxy jumps at you. -Not quite as nerveracking as the first game, while you have a little bit more multitasking this time around, you don't feel as vulnerable. if anything wanders nearby, you simply put on your Freddy head to disguise yourself until it leaves. This doesn't ruin the game, but it subtracts a little from the scariness.  Overall: I'm a huge 5NAF fan, and this game is amazing, if you're a fan you should download this now, I promise you won't regret it. I look forward to what Scott may bring us in the near future.

It's no secret that Five Nights at Freddy's was a complete success. The game was like none other I nor anyone else in the gaming community had seen before. As for the second game, much of the same thing can be said. This time around, the animtronics from the old location have been replaced with all new and improved versions. However, you will have to face the familiar four from the first game (now old and dismantled). To be honest, the old animtronics are what really sell the game for me. The new toy animtronics are not creepy at all. (Exept maybe mangle) The old animtronics however, Freddy is just plain creepy, bonnie's face is ripped off, Chica's jaw is hanging open, and foxy... well, he's just foxy. In this new installment, you have a freddy mask that you can put on and fool the animtronics into thinking you are one of them. This works quite well and works an all but two animtronics: Foxy and the Puppet who all talk about later. You also have a flashlight that can be used to shine into the hallway and can even be used to shine...light...in..the...cameras... ok am I the only one who questions the logic of the flashlight being able to be used in the cameras? Really, how does that even work? Anyway, speaking of cameras, you need to go into the cameras alot and I mean ALOT on account of a music box that you need to wind up to avoid being killed by the puppet that I mentioned because once it gets out, there's no stopping it. This is the one major problom that I have with FNAF 2. You don't need to look in any other camera exept the one with the music box. Sure in the first game pirates cove was the only thing you really needed to look at to check on foxy, but you only needed to check that for a second or two. Here, you need to sit there and wind the music box untill it is full. Also, for some reason there are vents in your office and animtronics can crawl through said vents and get into your office that way. Who the heck thought that having large gaping vents in your office was a good idea anyway? I mean it addsto the challange and al but it just seems a bit silly. Overall, I give Five Nights at Freddy's 2 a 9/10 for amazing gamplay, scary and cute and cuddly animtronics, and a boatload of other things. I just wish the camreas could be used for more than just winding a music box. I can recommend this game to anyone who is brave enough to play it.

This game is pretty darn good, and is a definite sequel (or prequel) to the first game, but this does have some of faults.  First of all, I think the music box mechanic wasn’t a good idea, as it reduces the monitor’s usage from a tool to keep track of what’s where to a big obscuring button to wind some music box. The box also winds down faster on later nights, making it sometimes impossible took keep it wound as the time it takes for the animatronics to leave the office and the vent openings becomes greater than the time it takes for the music box to wind down.  The Freddy Mask wasn’t a bad idea in my opinion, but the margin for error when using it is very thin (in the first game, you had quite a bit of time to react before something enters the office. In this, you have about a split-second to put on the mask before the game deems you were too slow).  Graphics-wise, this game doesn’t look bad, but for a 2014 game I’d expect something more. There are a lot of weird things involving light. All rooms viewed by the cameras seem to be lit by a dim, cool spotlight that seems to have no real source and the hanging lamp in your office lights everything EXECPT the vent openings and part of the hallway that it realistically should be lit. Although this doesn’t take away much from the gameplay, it would have made it more atmospheric if, for instance, rooms were lit by ambient light from windows and the office were lit by a small desk lamp.   Again, this game isn’t a bad game, but it could have been a lot better. I hope the next game both looks and feels better than this one. I hope to see possibly a new engine (Source 2.0?), better atmosphere, a more dynamic environment, and maybe a little voice acting wouldn’t hurt.

How the mighty have fallen.  Five Nights at Freddy's 1 was incredibly terrifying and quite difficult, but the reason why it was terrifying is that it went to great lengths to build up atmosphere and made it hard for you to know if an animatronic was coming for you until the last minute, and the reason it was difficult is because it would scare you into making frequent mistakes just because you're so nervous. The basic game was actually rather simple, but the framing device made it made it seem hard.  Five Nights at Freddy's 2 seems to have forgotten how to be scary. Where FNAF's animatronics evoked the unintentional creepiness of shoddily-made Chuck E Cheese characters, FNAF 2's new animatronics are shiny and cute and the only thing remotely frightening about them is their malevolence. Meanwhile, the old animatronics have been turned into mangled messes, abandoning the unintentional creepiness for deliberately freakish appearances, but this loses its fear factor very quickly because it just feels like it's trying too hard. What's more, the fact that the Freddy Fazbear head is a trump card against all but two animatronics -- and a trump card you can never ever not have available -- means that the two animatronics you can't use it against are the only ones that really matter, and everyone else is just annoying.  Now, FNAF 2 is certainly very difficult -- that part hasn't been lost. But it's difficult in the wrong way. FNAF 1 was hard because it stressed you out into making mistakes. FNAF 2 is hard because it gives you so many different things to manage and pure luck alone will determine whether or not you can manage them. A charitable interpretation of this might suggest that it's trying to evoke a different kind of horror: the futility of our illusion of control in a world where so little actually is in our control, a world where any one of us could do everything right in life and still get killed by a drunk driver or something out of nowhere tomorrow. But I'm not feeling charitable, I'm just feeling frustrated, and besides that kind of horror doesn't fit well with anything else in the atmosphere of the game, so no, it's just making the game hard for the sake of being hard because it wasn't scary.  Get this game only if you REALLY want to know the story of the series, because the one good thing it does is expand on the lore. Outside of that, it's a pretty bad sequel (or prequel, as the case may be) to the original.

As a person who enjoyed parts of the first game but found it to be overall lacking in actual horror, I am glad to say Five Nights 2 exceds the original in almost every way. While I still don't think the game is true horror, it is still fun to play and does a good job of creeping you the player out.   READY FOR FREDDY...  To those who played the original game and enjoyed it, you will be glad to know that much of what made the first game so popular is present in its sequel. You will once again find yourself as a security guard working the night shift at the newly re-opened Freddy Fazbears's Pizzaria. Much of the gameplay from the first game has been carried over, but with enough changes to make it feel new and not just a rehash of the original. You have a little tablet thing you use the check cameras and keep track of the animatronics as well as a few lights to check the area around you. The first thing you will notice right off the bat is you have no doors this time around, this time you are sitting in front of a wide open hallway and you must use a flashlight you have to light it up in order to check for enemies. There are also two air ducts on either side of you that you must check, giving three possible ways to get in in total. Another thing to note is that there are now six animatronics. Double the Freddy, still not ready. The last new addition is a music box that you have to make sure does not run out.   WHO GOES THERE?  As fun as the game is, it does have a few problems. For example, after night one the charge on the music box begins to drop faster and faster which adds to the tension. The problem is, because you have the music box to deal with as well as checking the vents and the hallway in front of you, you might as well keep your camera set on the room with the music box. The rest of the cameras become pretty much useless. And then there is the damn balloon boy, who will enter your room and start laughing without end thus rendering your lights useless and calling the attention of all of the animatronics (mainly Foxy). As of this moment I have no idea how to deal with the balloon boy, but he is super annoying and only serves to frustrate me instead of making the game more scary. The moment he appears in your room you might as well start over, because there is just no way of dealing with him that I am aware of. Not only that, but the game suffers from problems that the first game had as well. Because you're pretty much doing the same thing over and over again, there is a lack of replayability for you can only do the same thing over and over so many times before it gets dull.   DARK DESCENT...   All in all, Five Nights 2 is a fun game that surpasses the original in almost every way and should offer a few good jumps to those that play it. It might not be the best horror game ever, and it doesn't even come close to such masterpieces as Silent Hill 2 or Amnesia, but it does show that the horror genre still has life left in it and I will take it over games like Resident Evil 6 any day.  Peace and cupcakes,  Pyrin

No Doors, No Lights, No place to run, But one place to hide.  Five nights at freddy's 2 is a amazing action packed fast paced horror game that has you working five nights as a night security gaurd at a chucky chese style resturant, but the animotronics are out for blood.  Theres Freddy, Chica, Bonnie, Foxy (or mangle), and there broken counter parts, Withered Chica, Withered Bonnie, Withered Freddy And Withered Foxy The Pirate Fox. There are also side animotronics such as, Balloon Boy, The Puppet, and the ghostly golden freddy (or fredbear).  As you start the game, you are greeted to a long hallway in front of you, and two vents on the left and right. You can use the cameras, and you need to wind up a music box, or the beforte metioned puppet will come and decapatate you, to keep the rest of the animotronics at bay (excluding Foxy) you have a head that belongs to the mascott of the pizzarea, Freddy Fazbear. That fools the animotronics into thinking your one of them.  Comes night 2, you flash your light into the hallway to see Foxy. To take care of this pirate ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, you have to flash your light at him when he appears in your hall, easy enough right? Thats when Balloon Boy comes in, if he gets into your office (witch he can do fairly quickly) he disables your light, witch lets foxy lunge at you and remove your brain.  Story Spoliers Ahead, this is your warning  In this resturant, a man found a unused golden freddy suit in the back room. The man lured five innocent children into the back room using the suit, only to kill them. to hide there bodies he uses the animotronics in the backroom, and the golden freddy suit. After this, the toy animotronics (having facial reconition systems) reconize the criminal and try to kill him, but the man messes hacks the toy animotronics into thinking the night gaurd commited the crime, the children in the suit think your the killer as well, now all of them want your head.  The puppet however is a kid that was murdered at the first ever resturant witch was closed down after.  My opionion: Get this game!

I have been following Markiplier on YouTube for quite some time and was really interested in this Five Nights at Freddy's, then I saw he loaded up FNAF2, which seemed to hold more ominous and unsettling tones...Well, I downloaded the game last night and EVEN though I KNEW what was going to happen; anxiety set in moments after playing the game.  Midnight: Answer the phone...guy goes on his spiel. 1am: Everything is still where it needs to be... 2am: Oh no, where'd the bunny go?! Why can't I flick my lights down the- OH HII!! *starts having seizure flashing light at Foxy* 3am: Okay...he's gone. Wait, what's in the vents!? Oh HE'S ALREADY HERE!! *throws down Freddy face as Bonnie passes through; anxiety increases; music box alert flickering* 4am: Oh c'mon! Two more hours, oh the music box! Noo! *winds up music box; put down screen, sees Foxy and Chica* OH NOO! OH NO!! *flashes flashlight; down to one bar* 5am: Almost there...The balloon kids in the vents...I can hear you! *starts freaking out* OH! FOXY'S BACK!! *freaks out; hits alt-tab; frantically brings the game back up; clock ticks to 6am*  Me: OHH! I did it! I did it! Now...I can't play anymore. *cries to friend and makes him take over*  Long story short: Even though I knew what to expect, the noises and unsettling animatronics meandering the empty halls really gives this game a wonderful feel. I ended up making it to the 3rd night...but old Bonnie doesn't seem to like me very much. A game worth playing if you want to freak out yourself or your friends.

DISCLAMER : THIS REVEIW IS FOR THE FIRST FNAF GAME!!! NOT THE SECOND. Five Nights At Freddys is a game that will have you bitting your nails as soon as start your first nightshift as a secrurity guard at the fictional Freddy Fazbear Pizzaria. The games controls are simple, and easy to pick up, and ulike Five Nights At Freddys 2, (which i will talk about soon) You only use the mouse. This keeps things extremely easy, and makes i so that you don't have to mash keybored buttons and look down from your moniter at the same time, which is something i hate to do in horror games! The overall enviornment of the Pizzaria is nice, detailed, and creepy at the same time. (like if you were to walk into a chuck-e-cheese during a thunderstorm at night). This sets the whole tone of the game and really makes you want to get up and explore. This brings me to my next point, as far as we know now, Five Nights At Freddys 3 (which at the moment is in steam greenlight) will maintain the same formula as the last 2 games, the game is a point and click game, wchich means you cant get up and move around. Yes, your stuck sitting down and the mouse is your only way of exploring, by checking the cameras in the pizzaria of course. Is this such a big deal anyway???? In most other popular Horror games that have been a major hit over the years, have been a point and click, but given you the option to move around in a 3D enviornment. An exapmle could be Slenderman. I think the formula of the game works well, and that you dont have to worry about what is behind you! it also just kind of lets you focus on whats around you in your inviornment, and for me boosts my consentration knowing that i dont have to worry about something chasing me or me having to move around to collect things or explore different places. Anyways enough about the machanics, Now to the big point : Is it worth the 5 $ it is for sale at now??? Ok yes, the price was around 3 $ at some point late last year but they didnt raise it so much that it is ridiculus. For the quality and detail packed into the game, and the replayability, Annnnnnnnnnd the fact that it is super creepy and frightining at times, i beleave its worth the five dollars, unless you're just getting the game to use that new cheat Smike from youtube was talking about, Thumbs up! definitly a great buy and play! i really reconmend you ty it out soon!

This is a review of the entire series. No I will not review all of them, because, no, I don't want to buy all of them and waist a good $30 on games I don't like.  Five Nights at Freddy's blew up over the past year. And for no good reason other than Markiplier played it. Though he plays a lot of games that don't get the same attention as this one. So why was this so popular, I mean every body and their mother made a video about the game and it's hidden story, that's just that, hidden. And I think that's what made this game so popular. Five Nights played on that fear of the unknown, until you quickly figured out that games mechanics.  I hate when people call this game the best game of 2015, it really isn't. I couldn't even really name one, though the Early Alpha Sandbox for Yandere Simulator (another game being made by a single person as an independent developer) has much more innovation put into it than all of the Five Night's games put together.  Five Nights at Freddy's uses jump scares, and that's all it uses. There isn't anything else that makes this game 'scary' and at that the game isn't even scary, it's startling. The only time that the game is ever name stressful is when you're watching another person play it. And you can pick up the patterns that the animatronics use.  And the story is hidden. You shouldn't have to look for the story in a game that has one. There are plenty of games that just push you into the world without any explaination. And those don't need stories to them, a cryptic story is better than what Scott did. When you have to have the internet explain your story for you, you aren't doing your job correctly.  Age Rating: E 10+, For mild violence. The game is harmless, it couldn't hurt a fly if it tried to.  Overall Rating: 3/10 The game is not good, I paid money for a game that's made with the same quality as a free flash game on newgrounds. Hell Kiwi 64 had a better production quality and they don't charge a cent.

As much as I like the story concept, the gameplay can be challenging and at times... 'blah'. Why 'blah'? Being the second installment in the series, the game felt more stressful than terrifying, and by the time I finally played it, every YouTuber was done with this and spilled the beany secrets in the game. It was because of this that I didn't enjoy it as much as I could've.  Also, I want to express this opinion of mine that I've held for quite long: These FNAF games are meant to be strategic and make you think in a survivalist's situation, and the scares are only meant to keep you off focus. If you get past the horror aspect, it's nothing more but strategy. Think about it, will ya?

One word. Terrifying. To be honest, I knew when the jmpscares are going to happen so it didn't scare me that much. But everything else did. The stress. The setting. Old Bonnie and Old Chica(I freaking hate those two). I made it to night 5. If you like a stressful but fun and terrifying in a game, this is for you.

Unlike FNAF 1, there is much more to do this time. You now have to flash lights, wind up the music box, and put the Freddy head on. This game has a lot of easter eggs that are cool. Some of them are annoying. The only problem I have with this game is Balloon Boy who is annoying. Like the first game, the jumpscares become less scary, but they are more scary than the first. I forgot to mention that there are minigames if you die sometimes. Also the price isn't bad and I would even buy this game if it was at $10. Overall, this is a big improvement compared to the first game.
